position.marginalia_text: Tito Livio lacteum eloquentiae, ut ipsi dicunt, iam plaerique tribuunt

marginalia.translation: Most people now attribute to Livy “a pure [source?] of eloquence”, as they call it themselves.

position.marginalia_text: Haddonus ad Comitem Leicestrensem. Brugis. Equidem si rursus unq[uam] in Anglia constitero; et tibi ad it, temp[-] P[ub]lium Scipionem Africanum tibi familiarissimum reddam: [-] Nobilitatis exemplar, omnibus numeris expletum, et omnino [-] esse constituo. Ubi Plutarchi libru[m] valde illi commendat, de vita, et rebus gestis virorum illustrium

marginalia.translation: Haddon to the Count of Leicester, Bruges . For my part, if I will ever live in England again, [also . . . you to this . . .] I shall make you completely familiar with Publius Scipio Africanus: [whom] I consider an [. . .] example of nobility, perfect on all accounts, and fully [. . .]. Where he strongly recommends to him Plutarch’s book about the life and deeds of famous men.

position.marginalia_text: At nullius apud Livium excellentis viri insignior, nobiliorve Historia, quam Camilli Furii; et singularis viri, et unici Ducis suae aetatis; sive peritia rei militaris; sive animi, corporisq[ue] fortitudo, sive egregia Industria, Virtusq[ue] in exequendo, sive summa apud omnes auctoritas, optatissima in omnibus foelicitas spectanda videatur. Ante Camillum Furium pauci egregii Romani: ab illo admirabili Duce, tanq[uam] unico seminario illius strenuae, praevalidaeq[ue] virtutis Romanae, quanta seges fortissimorum virorum, Ducumq[ue] toto orbe clarissimoru[m]? Quod David apud Hebraeos, Cyrus apud Persas, Hector apud Troianos, Achilles apud Graecos, Epaminondas apud Thebanos, Alexander apud Macedones, unici apud suos, et invicti Duces: id apud Romanos Camillus, potentissimus suo tempore Imperator, et singulare exemplar tot acrium validorumq[ue] Romanorum, quot post eum sunt a Livio magnifice percelebrati. Quod tantopere floruerit illa Respublica, tandemq[ue] Orbis Domina regnarit; in causa fuisse pute[m], non ipsum Reipublicae politicum statum, qui non erat certe ad imperandum, aut gubernandum optimus; sed raros quosdam, et excellentissimos viros, maxime Senatores, ac Magistratus, qui partim Legum, partim Armorum peritissimi, et perpetua aemulatione flagrantes honoratissimarum domi, forisq[ue] actionum; quicquid Romanae virtutis, dignitatisque interesse videbatur, id omne serio consilio, fortissimaq[ue] industria moliebantur. Respondit Fortuna Virtuti: et hinc strenuaru[m], ingentiumq[ue] Actionum quanta messis, ecquanta publice, privatimq[ue] gloria? Unde non tam a publica gubernationis forma, quam a publicarum personaru[m] prudentia, atque virtute, illa florentissimae Reipublicae, potentissimiq[ue] imperii magnitudo. Ecce igitur summorum, singulariumq[ue] virorum res gestae, egregia facinora, mnemosyna, quicquid exstat in civitate, campove memorabile: et quae sunt in Monarchia victuro aptissima, ea curiosius observanda, diligentius applicanda ad suum usum. Caetera Aristocratica, et Democratica tanti facienda, quantum meruerunt in Monarchia aestimari; salvo Iure Regiae Maiestatis, nullo modo laedendae, aut praeiudicandae. Nam populares humores, ut etiam philosophicas venas, omnesq[ue] phantasticos appetitus temperare oportet in Principatu: et Subditorum qualitates, quantumvis praestantissimorum, ad Statum Principis conformare: nec populi, Optimatumve arcana in Regum acta, consiliave intrudere. In quo saepe fallunt plaeriq[ue] Regii consiliarii, Magistratus, Ministri: nescientes perite, solideq[ue] distinguere inter singulos Rerumpublicarum status, eorumq[ue] propria politeumata. Hinc mille in Conciliis, Actisq[ue] publicis Errores. Laudantur in Historiis dicta, factaq[ue] eorum, qui sunt habiti apud suos sapientissimi, fortissimi, iustissimi. Sed multu[m] interest, cuiusmodi politicus dicat, faciatve, et quem ad finem, et in quo genere Reipublicae et in quo singulari casu. Pro suo quisq[ue] Statu, vel publico, vel privato: et nemo ligat sibi manus. Multa in Rep[ublica] Romana dicta actaq[ue] prudentissime, quae in Regno, et in hac aetate dicerentur, forentq[ue] absurde. Sine Iudicio nihil sapit: et Aptum esse convenit quicquid est laudabile. Gh . 1580 .

marginalia.translation: Yet no story in Livy of an outstanding man is more remarkable and noble than that of Camillus Furius, who is both an extraordinary man and a singular Leader of his age. Whether it is his military expertise, his mental and physical strength, his outstanding diligence and excellence in executing [his task], or the very high esteem everybody has for him, it seems his good fortune in everything should be considered his most desired quality. Before Camillus Furius there were few outstanding Romans. Yet what a tremendous crop of the most courageous men and leaders most illustrious in the whole world has emerged from this wonderful Leader, as if from a unique seedbed of that vigorous, superbly powerful Roman excellence! What David was among the Jews, Cyrus among the Persians, Hector among the Trojans, Achilles among the Greeks, Epaminondas among the Thebans, Alexander among the Macedonians: incomparable and invincible Leaders – that is Camillus among the Romans, the most powerful Commander of his time, and a remarkable example of so many vigorous and strong Romans, as after him Livy has made superbly and thoroughly known. That this Republic flourished to such a great degree and at last governed as a Ruler of the World, was possible, I would think, not because of the political institution of the Republic, which was certainly not the best one for ruling, or governing, but because of several exceptional, most brilliant men, especially senators and officers; fully practised, some in law, others in arms, and burning with the permanent desire to surpass the most honourable deeds at home and abroad; whatever seemed to serve Roman excellence and dignity, they attempted all of it with serious judgement and the strongest care. Fortune responded to Virtue: and how great a harvest came from these vigorous, tremendous deeds, and what great fame, public as well as private! From which [follows] that that particular greatness of the flourishing Republic and of its extremely powerful rule was not so much a product of the public form of government, as of the insight and virtue of its public men. Pay attention, therefore, to the exploits of remarkable men, their outstanding deeds, records, whatever impressive feat there can be found in the state or on the field. And one must note even more carefully the things that are most convenient for prevailing in a monarchy, and apply them very scrupulously to one's own purpose. The remaining aristocratic and democratic actions should be valued according to the esteem they earned in a monarchy, without detriment to the authority of Royal Majesty, which must not be harmed or prejudged in any way. For in a Principate one ought to moderate popular sentiments, just like philosophical veins as well, and all fanciful desires, and to align the qualities of the subjects to the state of the Prince, no matter how very pre-eminent they may be, and not to force private matters of the people or of the aristocracy upon the acts or plans of Kings. In this respect most royal counsels, magistrates and ministers err. For they do not know to distinguish skillfully and solidly between particular political situations of republics, and their own policies. This caused a thousand errors in public councils and acts. In Histories words and deeds are praised of those considered the wisest, bravest and most righteous among their fellow people. But it makes a big difference what kind of politician is speaking or doing something, and to what purpose, and in what sort of Republic, and in what particular instance. Each one acts in the interests of his own situation, whether public of private, and no-one binds his own hands. In the Roman Republic many things were most prudently said and done, which would be absurd, if they were expressed in a Kingdom and in this age. Without judgment one does not know anything. And being useful is suitable for whatever is praiseworthy. G[abriel] H[arvey], 1580
